title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 ยง 1204.2 - Vehicle size and weight limitations
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 ยง 1204.2 - Vehicle size and weight limitations

State Regulations
(a) Length. (1)

Single vehicles having an over-all length
of more than 45 feet, including their load. (2)

Dual vehicles having an over-all length
of more than 85 feet for the combination, including their load. (b) Width. Vehicles having an outside over-all width of more than
eight feet six inches, including their load, and vehicles equipped with
pneumatic tires having an over-all width not exceeding eight feet eight inches, the bodies of which, including load, do not exceed eight feet six
inches. (c) Side
overhang-tunnels only. Vehicles, up to and including 11 feet six inches above
the roadway, with a side overhang, including load, of more than 11 inches
beyond the rim of the wheel. No side overhang is permitted above 11 feet six
inches. (d) Height. (1)

Bridges-vehicles, including their loads, having an over-all height of more than 14 feet from the
roadway. (2)

George Washington

Bridge Expressway-vehicles, including their loads, having an over-all height of
more than 13 feet six inches from the roadway. (3)

Tunnels-vehicles, including their loads, exceeding 13 feet in height at the Lincoln Tunnel, and vehicles, including
their loads, exceeding 12 feet six inches in height at the Holland

Tunnel. (e) Weight. (1)

Single vehicles
having two axles, when the gross weight, including the load, exceeds 40,000
pounds; and single vehicles having three or more axles, when the gross weight, including the load, exceeds 50,000 pounds. (2)

Dual vehicles having three axles, when
the gross weight, including the load, exceeds 60,000 pounds; and dual vehicles
having four or more axles, when the gross weight, including the load, exceeds
70,000 pounds. (3)

Single axles, when the gross weight thereon, including load, exceeds 32,000 pounds; and
tandem axles (consecutive axles not less than 40 inches apart, nor more than
eight feet apart) when the gross weight thereon, including load, exceeds 20,000
pounds per axle. TABLE I
